bibl.title: Analysis of Basic Cost, Camp Lazear, by Paul L. Tate, [19--]

div1.p: Tate analyzes the checkbook stubs for Camp Lazear. He thinks that Lambert has reason to feel upset, because he nursed yellow fever patients and the only extra check made out to him was for $20.

div1.head: Analysis of Basic Cost, Camp Lazear, by Paul L. Tate, [19--]

head.hi: ANALYSIS OF BASIC COSTS, CAMP LAZEAR

list.item:

item.p:

$ 601.LABOR-The names of A.H.S. Burton and Cook do not appear, so
I presume they did not remain after the Camp opened.
John Morris was sent there after the Camp opened, but
he evidently received no extra pay.

div1.p:
These cheeck-book figures are very interesting and revealing of things
(2)
I never knew. Of course, General Truby and Doctor Hench, with
more inside information, these figures may be more illuminating,
but, just through curiosity I have attempted to analyze them.

I know nothing factually about those Spanish volunteers except
that they were there, but I notice a diversity of names in dif-
ferent places regarding them: Yes
The Senate Doc. gave me what info I had,

Check-book figures show two named Fernandez as receivers of $200.
each for experiment. (Martinez as receiving $50.)

Photostat list of patients at Camp Lazear show two named Fernan-
dez.

Notes to picture, “Conquorers of Yellow Fever” show one named
Fernandez and one named Martinez.
Gen. Truby's book shows one Fernandez and one Martinez.

That is the only authority I have at hand. From it I would think
that two named Fernandez was correct, being original entries;
i,e, Ni cenes Fernandez, 4th patient, Dec. 15th, 1900-Jan. 3, '01.
and Jose A. Fernandez, 6th patient, Jan. 2,-Jan. 13,1901.

He was used by Reed very much, more than any of the Spaniards
Martinez does not appear on original List of Patients at Camp
Lazear, which I have. He appears only on Check-book entries as
receiving $50. only, so I would presume that he never contracted
Yellow Fever at Camp Lazear. (This may well be a mix-up in Span-
ish names, later solved by someone with better knowledge.)
I don't see where Jernegan received anything for his mosquito
test. There is $100. for fomite test, $200. for blood test, but
the idea I received at the time was that each man received $100.
for each test and $200. if he contracted the disease.. He re-
ceived same amount as Folk who took two tests.

I don't see any checks made out to Lambert except one for $20.
for labor before experiment started. No wonder the poor fellow
feels sore.--All that money floating around, given to Privates
in addition to regular pay, and he taking chances every day,
(before the mosquito theory was established) that exceeded all
of them put together. He was practically a volunteer, as no
nurse in Cuba, as I remember, was ever detailed to nurse Y.F.
against his will. Lambert was an isolated untouchable, cut off
from all mankind except Y. F. victims and Dr. Ames, and the
only pay he received was as a Private of thee H. C.. A very
great injustice, I would term it.

Total approximate cost according to Check-book: $5,505. But
there are many items that do not appear there. For instance,
I suppose all the bedding and clothing that Lambert consigned
to flames on the other side of the cut, not having facilities
to disinfect and wash them, (even if he had the time to do so)
were Hospital Supply items. But it was extra expense and it
seems should be charged to the Experiment.
